feedback_text:
I decided to give Revolut another try after several years, and unfortunately the experience was just as frustrating as before.
In the past, I repeatedly ran into security and verification issues - multiple uploads of my driver's license, facial photos, and even a video call with support - before eventually giving up. Recently, I opened a new account and completed the full identity verification process again, including scanning my driver's license and submitting a face scan.
Everything initially appeared to be successful.
When I attempted to add funds, I encountered an error. Shortly after, l received an email stating that my account would be closed because Revolut was unable to verify my identity. I filed an appeal and submitted additional documentation, including my driver's license and a recent paycheck stub. Despite this, Revolut upheld their decision without providing any specific explanation. At no point was I told what was missing, incorrect, or how the issue could be resolved. I fully understand identity verification and AML requirements, but being asked to repeatedly provide documentation
— only to have the account closed anyway — is a poor user experience and a significant waste of time.
If you value transparency and a smooth onboarding process, this app may not be a good fit.

I decided to give Revolut another try after several years, and unfortunately the experience was just as frustrating as before.
In the past, I repeatedly ran into security and verification issues - multiple uploads of my driver's license, facial photos, and even a video call with support - before eventually giving up. Recently, I opened a new account and completed the full identity verification process again, including scanning my driver's license and submitting a face scan.
Everything initially appeared to be successful.
When I attempted to add funds, I encountered an error. Shortly after, l received an email stating that my account would be closed because Revolut was unable to verify my identity. I filed an appeal and submitted additional documentation, including my driver's license and a recent paycheck stub. Despite this, Revolut upheld their decision without providing any specific explanation.
At no point was I told what was missing, incorrect, or how the issue could be resolved. I fully understand identity verification and AML requirements, but being asked to repeatedly provide documentation
- only to have the account closed anyway — is a poor user experience and a significant waste of time. If you value transparency and a smooth onboarding process, this app may not be a good fit.

I was excited about Revolut after reading all the positive reviews (they were overwhelmingly positive even after sorting by
"Most recent," which gives a more accurate picture of an app than the "Most helpful" sort, which is most helpful to Apple and the creators of the app rather than to prospective users), but having now completed (most of) the account setup process, l'm dismayed: Revolut charges fees for almost everything that many real banks provide free, such as ATM access and a physical debit card. (The developers may respond to this saying the debit card is free, but that would be them hiding behind language: they don't say they charge you for the card per se, but they do charge a $2.99 delivery fee..which equals charging for the card.) Revolut charges $9.99 per month for an account with features comparable to those I get from Discover Bank for free, and offers another account tier for $16.99/month that gets you a metal debit card and several add-on services that have nothing to do with banking (mostly fitness classes and such...what??) and that themselves offer higher, paid tiers - so you're basically just paying to have Revolut market more products to you.
Revolut may be good for people with extra money to whom the appearances of buff bodies and metal debit cards are important, but it's not my thing and I do not recommend it.

I'll probably stick with it and just track my bills in a spreadsheet for now, but I'm disappointed to have gone through all this work switching just to have less clarity/ assurance about my bills being accounted for. I thought that was the whole point.
